channel.title: How To Create Custom DNS Cache (Windows XP)
channel.description:
Well, the function of a DNS server is to point a domain to an IP address. This tweak will explain how to reference a built in DNS in Windows XP Professional.
1) First, open your favourite text editor. 2) Next, navigate to [code]C:\WINDOWS\system32\drivers\etc[/code] 3) Open up terminal and [code]cd C:\WINDOWS\system32\drivers\etc[/code] 4) In terminal, [code]attrib -R hosts[/code] 5) Now, in the text editor open 'hosts' in the etc directory.
You should see something of this nature:
[code] # Copyright (c) 1993-1999 Microsoft Corp. # # This is a sample HOSTS file used by Microsoft TCP/IP for Windows. # # This file contains the mappings of IP addresses to host names. Each # entry should be kept on an individual line. The IP address should # be placed in the first column followed by the corresponding host name. # The IP address and the host name should be separated by at least one # space. # # Additionally, comments (such as these) may be inserted on individual # lines or following the machine name denoted by a '#' symbol.
127.0.0.1 localhost [/code]
Below the [code]127.0.0.1 localhost[/code] line, you can add more entries.
Example: [code]209.85.171.100 google.com[/code]
Now, this will point the domain google.com to 209.85.171.100 no matter what application you're using.
Save, exit, Back In terminal, [code]attrib +R hosts[/code], test, enjoy!

item.title: How To Create Custom DNS Cache (Windows XP)
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:2, topic:266787”]Lol I need to do this on my Mates PC and redirect all his favourite websites to some shock site.
Is there a actual useful purpose for this anyway?[/quote]
i’ve seen a small business use the host file to change the companyweb domain they taught all the workers to goto businessname.com/employee at work for the companyweb which would just redirect to /localserver2/

Read full topic
item.source: How To Create Custom DNS Cache (Windows XP)

item.title: How To Create Custom DNS Cache (Windows XP)
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Well, the function of a DNS server is to point a domain to an IP address. This tweak will explain how to reference a built in DNS in Windows XP Professional.

  1. First, open your favourite text editor.
  2. Next, navigate to C:\WINDOWS\system32\drivers\etc
  3. Open up terminal and cd C:\WINDOWS\system32\drivers\etc
  4. In terminal, attrib -R hosts
  5. Now, in the text editor open ‘hosts’ in the etc directory.

You should see something of this nature:

# Copyright (c) 1993-1999 Microsoft Corp.
#
# This is a sample HOSTS file used by Microsoft TCP/IP for Windows.
#
# This file contains the mappings of IP addresses to host names. Each
# entry should be kept on an individual line. The IP address should
# be placed in the first column followed by the corresponding host name.
# The IP address and the host name should be separated by at least one
# space.
#
# Additionally, comments (such as these) may be inserted on individual
# lines or following the machine name denoted by a '#' symbol.

127.0.0.1       localhost

Below the 127.0.0.1 localhost line, you can add more entries.

Example: 209.85.171.100 google.com

Now, this will point the domain google.com to 209.85.171.100 no matter what application you’re using.

Save, exit, Back In terminal, attrib +R hosts, test, enjoy!

Read full topic
item.source: How To Create Custom DNS Cache (Windows XP)
